t: Habakkuk 3
Habakkuk’s Prayer
A*i prayer*i of*i Habakkuk*i the*i prophet.*i On*i shigionoth.*i
Lord,*spn I have heard of your fame; I*ld stand in awe of your deeds, Lord.*s Repeat*ln them in our day, in*ld our time make them known; in*ld wrath remember mercy.
God*pn came from Teman, the*ld Holy One from Mount Paran. His*ln glory covered the heavens and*ld his praise filled the earth.
His*ln splendor was like the sunrise; rays*ld flashed from his hand, where*ld his power was hidden.
Plague*ln went before him; pestilence*ld followed his steps.
He*ln stood, and shook the earth; he*ld looked, and made the nations tremble. The*ln ancient mountains crumbled and*ld the age-old hills collapsed— but*ld he marches on forever.
I*ln saw the tents of Cushan in distress, the*ld dwellings of Midian in anguish.
Were*pn you angry with the rivers, Lord?*s Was*ld your wrath against the streams? Did*ln you rage against the sea when*ld you rode your horses and*ld your chariots to victory?
You*ln uncovered your bow, you*ld called for many arrows. You*ln split the earth with rivers;
the*ld mountains saw you and writhed. Torrents*ln of water swept by; the*ld deep roared and*ld lifted its waves on high.
Sun*pn and moon stood still in the heavens at*ld the glint of your flying arrows, at*ld the lightning of your flashing spear.
In*ln wrath you strode through the earth and*ld in anger you threshed the nations.
You*ln came out to deliver your people, to*ld save your anointed one. You*ln crushed the leader of the land of wickedness, you*ld stripped him from head to foot.
With*ln his own spear you pierced his head when*ld his warriors stormed out to scatter us, gloating*ln as though about to devour the*ld wretched who were in hiding.
You*ln trampled the sea with your horses, churning*ld the great waters.

I*pn heard and my heart pounded, my*ld lips quivered at the sound; decay*ln crept into my bones, and*ld my legs trembled. Yet*ln I will wait patiently for the day of calamity to*ld come on the nation invading us.

Though*ln the fig tree does not bud and*ld there are no grapes on the vines, though*ln the olive crop fails and*ld the fields produce no food, though*ln there are no sheep in the pen and*ld no cattle in the stalls,
yet*ln I will rejoice in the Lord,*s I*ld will be joyful in God my Savior.
The*pn Sovereign Lord*s is my strength; he*ld makes my feet like the feet of a deer, he*ld enables me to tread on the heights. For*pn the director of music. On my stringed instruments.
